text:
Mathematical Reflection Implementation Investigation 1

The Mathematical Reflection provides an opportunity to discuss the goals of the Investigation. Students can pull together their reasoning from the Now What Do You Know to summarize their learning over the time (TIME).

After the class discussion, students can record their responses to the Mathematical Reflection to create a record of their current understandings of the big ideas of the Unit.

A teacher can gain an understanding of student thinking during a discussion of the reflection question. Then one can assess individual understanding based on each student’s written work.

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Work to build and connect mathematical understandings for key aspects of probability and proportional reasoning.

Notice that students recognize:

  • Conducting an experiment can give data that can be used for making future decisions
  • Outcomes are the possible results in an event
  • When conducting an experiment, you must make sure to do it as randomly as possible
  • Doing many trials of an experiment helps to find trends in what is most likely to occur
  • Experimental probability is the ratio of (Number of desired outcomes)/(Total number of outcomes)
  • Proportional reasoning can be used to scale up or down the experimental probabilities to make predictions
  • To decide if outcomes are equally likely you need to consider all possible outcomes
  • You need to look at each outcome to decide if each has an equal chance of occurring
  • Equally likely is important to consider because it helps to select future outcomes
  • Equally likely is important to consider because it helps to determine if an event is fair
  • Equally likely does not necessarily mean outcome are 50-50

Mathematical Reflection

What do you know about probability? About proportional relationships?

Student Responses

Each Investigation contributes to students’ conceptual understandings of the ideas in the Unit. Students’ explanations at the beginning of a Unit might be just forming. As you progress through the Unit, students can use the contexts, representation, and connections to express a more solid understanding. By the end of the Unit, students can create a complete picture of understanding.

What do you know about probability? About proportional relationships?

(At this point students can talk about finding experimental probabilities. They know that using more trials in experimental probabilities is more accurate for making predictions, and that to determine if a situation is equally likely they need to find all possible outcomes/)

Reflecting on Student Learning

Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.

  • What in evidence in students’ work shows an understanding of the ideas in this Unit?
  • What mathematical ideas will still need emphasis?
  • What opportunities exist in the rest of the Unit, or in future Units, to extend and connect the students’ learning?

Mathematical Practice Implementation

Every day, students use “habits of mind” to make sense of problems and apply learning to new situations. Some of these habits are described by the Common Core State Standards for Mathematical Practices (MP). Using the Mathematical Practices Reflections at the close of each Investigation allows students to name their reasoning.

Students demonstrate to themselves (AGENCY, IDENTITY, OWNERSHIP) the power of the Practices.

Some teachers discuss the Mathematical Practices during the Summarize of Problems where a specific practice was evident and widely used by students. This can enhance students’ understanding of their mathematical learning and processing.

  • What mathematical practice did the students use to solve this Problem? (Answers will vary. Students may relate their work to MP6 Attend to precision, MP5 Uses appropriate tools strategically, MP7 Look for and make use of structure, or MP8 Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning. )
  • What other mathematical practices did you use to solve Problems in this Investigation? (Answers will vary. MP1 Make sense of Problems and persevere in solving them can always be mentioned for CMP Problems.)

Mathematical Reflection Implementation Investigation 2

The Mathematical Reflection provides an opportunity to discuss the goals of the Investigation. Students can pull together their reasoning from the Now What Do You Know to summarize their learning over the time (TIME).

After the class discussion, students can record their responses to the Mathematical Reflection to create a record of their current understandings of the big ideas of the Unit.

A teacher can gain an understanding of student thinking during a discussion of the reflection question. Then one can assess individual understanding based on each student’s written work.

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Work to build and connect mathematical understandings for key aspects of probability and proportional reasoning.

Begin the understanding that theoretical probability can further students understanding of predicting future events.

Notice that students can:

  • Examine a game and determine all the possible outcomes
  • Analyze and count the number of times each outcome will occur
  • Notice that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1
  • Explain that larger numbers indicate a greater likelihood that an outcome will occur
  • Recognize that a probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event¬
  • Continue looking at whether outcomes are equally likely for an event
  • Show that the sum of theoretical probabilities for all possible outcome is always 1
  • Recognize that for some events only experimental data is used to make predictions
  • Notice that experimental probability changes and gets closer to the theoretical probability as more data is collected
  • Create probability models to find probabilities of events that include organized lists and tree diagrams
  • Expand the idea of equally likely by relating it to the fairness of a game
  • Use proportional reasoning to make predictions based on the theoretical probabilities of a game
  • Describe a compound event as a game that consists of two events
  • Recognize that organized lists and tree diagrams can be used to find the possible outcomes for compound events
  • Understand that a spinner can be used to determine experimental probability. The area of the spinner is subdivided to represent each event
  • Understand that using the results of experimental trials, you can predict future outcomes
  • Understand that to find theoretical probability with a spinner you would have to determine the portion of the area of the spinner to determine how likely a result might be.

Mathematical Reflection

What do you know about probability? About proportional relationships?

Student Responses

Each Investigation contributes to students’ conceptual understandings of the ideas in the Unit. Students’ explanations at the beginning of a Unit might be just forming. As you progress through the Unit, students can use the contexts, representation, and connections to express a more solid understanding. By the end of the Unit, students can create a complete picture of understanding.

What do you know about probability? About proportional relationships?

(At this point students can talk about theoretical probabilities, fairness in games, tree diagrams, organized lists and compound events.)

Reflecting on Student Learning

Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.

  • What in evidence in students’ work shows an understanding of the ideas in this Unit?
  • What mathematical ideas will still need emphasis?
  • What opportunities exist in the rest of the Unit, or in future Units, to extend and connect the students’ learning?

Mathematical Practice Implementation

Every day, students use “habits of mind” to make sense of problems and apply learning to new situations. Some of these habits are described by the Common Core State Standards for Mathematical Practices (MP). Using the Mathematical Practices Reflections at the close of each Investigation allows students to name their reasoning.

Students demonstrate to themselves (AGENCY, IDENTITY, OWNERSHIP) the power of the Practices.

Some teachers discuss the Mathematical Practices during the Summarize of Problems where a specific practice was evident and widely used by students. This can enhance students’ understanding of their mathematical learning and processing.

  • What mathematical practice did the students use to solve this Problem? (Answers will vary. . Students may relate their work to MP2 Reason abstractly and quantitatively; or MP3 Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others; or MP7 Look for and make use of structure)
  • What other mathematical practices did you use to solve Problems in this Investigation? (Answers will vary. MP1 Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them can always be mentioned for CMP Problems.)
